column2: Confucianism was found by the Chinese philosopher Confucius (Kong Fuzi ("Master Kong"), born Kong Qiu) in the 5th century B.C. The religion flourished not only China, but also heavily influenced society in other parts of East Asia such as Korea, Japan, and Vietnam. In the game, Confucians get a bonus to dynasty opinion, meaning that they might not need to watch their own kin as closely.

§Y*§! Rulers can spend Te to improve their Courtiers' Attribute.
§Y*§! Has access to ancestor worship.
§Y*§! Has access to two different religious schools.
§Y*§! Unlocks access to the §YChinese Imperial§!, §YEastern Imperial§!, and §YConfucian Bureaucracy§! governments.
§Y*§! Can NOT declare Holy Wars
column3: §Y*§! Ne peut pas déclarer de guerre sainte

column2: Shinto, also known as "Kami-no-michi" (the Way of the Gods), is the indigenous religion of Japan. Despite many of its adherents initially being opposed to the introduction of Buddhism in Japan, the Shinto religion has incorporated many Buddhist aspects over time. The Shinto religion teaches that certain deeds create a kind of ritual impurity, which one should want to have cleansed for one's own peace of mind and good fortune rather than a negative connotation of such impurity, and also focuses on ritual practices to establish a connection between one self and their ancestors. In the game, Shinto followers get a significant bonus to Intrigue, meaning that court life becomes significantly more dangerous. Though the religion lacks a clear hierarchy, the Tenno is represented as the religious head due to having an important ceremonial position.

§Y*§! Has access to ancestor worship.\n§Y*§! Unlocks access to the §YJapanese Bureaucracy§!, §YJapanese Feudal§!, and §YJapanese Monastic Feudal§! governments.\§Y*§! Can easily gain Sympathy for Pagans.\n§Y*§! Can NOT declare Holy Wars
column3: §Y*§! Ne peut pas déclarer de guerre sainte

column2: Shugendo (the Way of Trial and Practice) is a highly syncretic religion tracing its origin to the mystic En no Gyoja, who lived in the Nara period. The religion blends elements of Shinto mountain worship and Buddhism in a unique manner. Practitioners, known as Shugenja or Yamabushi (Mountain Prostrators), strive to find supernatural power and to save themselves and the massese through religious training undertaken while treading through steep mountain ranges all over Japan.
§Y*§! Unlocks access to the §YJapanese Bureaucracy§! and §YJapanese Feudal§! governments.\n§Y*§! Can easily gain Sympathy for Pagans.\n§Y*§! Can NOT declare Holy Wars
column3: §Y*§! Ne peut pas déclarer de guerre sainte

column2: Koshin is a Japanese religion with Taoist origins, blending Taoist, Shinto, Buddhist, and other beliefs. The believers seek to prevent the Sanshi (the Three Corpses) from leaving their bodies, seeing as the Sanshi would report on their deeds to Ten-Tei.
§Y*§! Unlocks access to the §YJapanese Bureaucracy§! and §YJapanese Feudal§! governments.\n§Y*§! Can NOT declare Holy Wars
column3: §Y*§! Ne peut pas déclarer de guerre sainte

column2: The Kejawèn religion blends various Hindu, Buddhist, and animistic aspects into a unique religion. The religion originated on the island of Java as a consequence of Indian influences mixing with the local beliefs.
§Y*§! Can easily gain Sympathy for Pagans.\n§Y*§! Rulers may search for a guru.\n§Y*§! Can only declare limited Holy Wars against non-[GetDharmicOrRandom] religions

column2: The reformed Ainu faith has a Holy Book containing the Ainu creation myth, information about various kamuy, and written renditions of several important yukar. The church also has a standardized liturgy and a formal church hierarchy, rather than relying on disorganized shamans and fortune-tellers.

Ainu paganism is an animistic religion, believing that everything in nature in Ainu Mosir (the Land of the People) has a kamuy, an immortal spirit or god originating in Kamuy Mosir (the Land of the Gods). Bears are seen as particularly important, and hunters traiditionally seek to capture bear cubs to raise in their villages until the cub has grown up, at which point the bear is ritually sacrificed as part of the Iyomante ceremony to return the kamuy to Kamuy Mosir.
§Y*§! Has access to ancestor worship.\n§Y*§! Inferior at conversion\n§Y*§! Rulers cannot declare Holy Wars

column2: The reformed Andamanese faith has a Holy Book, a standardized liturgy and a formal church hierarchy.

The traditional Andamanese beliefs are animistic and contain elements of ancestor worship. The faithful believe that they are the descendants of the survivors of a great flood caused by a failure to follow divine laws.

column2: By taking various elements of Taoism, Confucianism, and even Buddhism and blending these with traditional Benzhuist beliefs, the reformed Benzhuist faith has managed to create a standardized Holy Book and liturgy, and a formal church hierarchy.
Benzhuism is the folk religion of the Bai people. The faithful venerate their ancestors, particularly those that are considered to be among the Benzhu.

column2: The reformed version of Nat worship has a clear pantheon of deified ancestors and nature spirits, as well as a holy book containing the canonical version of various holy legends, a standardized liturgy and a formal church hierarchy.
Nat worship is the traditional religion of the Burmese peoples, venerating the Nats, which are deified ancestors, nature spirits, and even a few Hindu gods.

The Pemena faith is the traditional religion of the Batak people and puts a great emphasis on ancestor veneration and familial lines.

column2: By taking various elements of Taoism, Confucianism, and even Buddhism and blending these with traditional Shenist beliefs, the reformed Shenist faith has managed to create a standardized Holy Book and liturgy, and a formal church hierarchy.

Shenism, Wuism, or Nuoism, is the folk religion of China with multitudes of doctrines and practices. Due to its sheer size and spread, it has influenced if not founded the other local folk religions of both Far East and South East Asia. Its widespread beliefs has resulted in more organized forms of the religion such as Confucianism and Taoism.

column2: The reformed Kaharingan faith has a holy book containing the canonical version of various holy legends, a standardized liturgy and a formal church hierarchy.

Kaharinganism is the folk religion of the Dayak people in Borneo. They are known for their long festivals called the Tiwah festival, which lasts for thirty days, and involves the sacrifice of many animals such as buffaloes, cows, pigs, and chickens as offerings to the gods.

column2: The reformed Momolian faith has a Holy Book, a standardized liturgy and a formal church hierarchy.
Momolianism is the folk religion of the Dusun people in Borneo. The religion teaches that all land is a gift from the creator god Minamangun.

column2: The Inca religion of Yupaychaspa is a polytheistic faith system with the sun god Inti at the head. Unlike its unreformed counterpart, the faith has a holy book containing the canonical version of various holy legends, a standardized liturgy and a formal church hierarchy
The Inca religion of Yupaychaspa is a polytheistic faith system with the sun god Inti at the head, practiced throughout the Quechua lands on both sides of the Pacific Ocean.

The reformed Jurchen religion has standardized the many legends of [jurchen_pagan_reformed.GetHighGodName] and the other deities and spirits, and has a Holy Book, a standardized liturgy and a formal church hierarchy.
The traditional Jurchen religion involves belief in several gods and spirits, chief among them Abka Hehe ("Sky Woman" or "Sky Mother"). Female shamans are quite common, as is ancestor veneration.

column2: The reformed Muist faith has a standardized Holy Book containing founding legends and appropriate sacrifices to both gods and ancestors, as well as a formal church hierarchy.

Muism, or Sinism, is the pre-historic shamanistic folk religion of Korea, which shares some similarities with other religions originating nearby, such as Taoism and Confucianism. Purity is important to the rituals performed.

column2: The reformed Anito faith has a Holy Book, a standardized liturgy and a formal church hierarchy.

The traditional beliefs of the Ma-i-an peoples are varied, but they tend to involve belief in a parallel spirit world as well as omnipresent spirits (or Anito) that can influence things in this world.

column2: The reformed Melanesian religion is a fusion of many popular beliefs, with a single Holy Book including a creation myth and chapters on rites and rituals. The church also has a standardized liturgy and a formal church hierarchy.
The Melanesian religion represents the diverse pagan beliefs of the tribes of the Pacific Islands. Some of the uniform distinctive practices are mortuary rites, headhunting, and agrarian rituals.

The Kev Dab Qhuas religion is highly animistic and teaches that people and nature spirits should show mutual respect for each other. Elements of Buddhism and Taoism are sometimes interwowen with these traditional beliefs.

column2: Having standardized the songs and myths about the creation of the world and the ancient battles between heroes, spirits, and beast, the reformed Nivkh religion has created a dedicated Holy Book, a standardized liturgy and a formal church hierarchy.

The traditional Nivkh beliefs are animistic. The faithful believe that the island of Sakhalin is a giant beast lying on its belly, and that upsetting this beast causes the earth to shake. They also have a pantheon of gods of the mountains, seas, rivers, and sky.has a Holy Book, a standardized liturgy and a formal church hierarchy.

column2: The reformed Ryukyuan faith has a written history detailing the founding of the world and how certain dynasties have divine ancestry, as well as a more formal religious hierarchy than before reformation.

The Ryukyuan religion is an indigenous belief system to the people of the Ryukyu Islands having animistic roots. Though similar to the Japanese Shinto religion, Ryukyuans believe in the concept of onarigami, the spiritual superiority of women, in stark contrast to Shinto.

Bimoism is the traditional religion of the Yi people. It is named after the Bimo priests, recognized by their distinctive black robes and large hats. The religion puts an emphasis on the veneration of ancestors, as well as of dragons.

Mo, or Mohism, is the traditional religion of the Zhuang people. Its supreme god is the creator Baeuqloxdoh, the ruler of the earth. Unlike the traditional belief in four or even five elements, the Mohists believe in three elements, namely sky, earth, and water.
